'Tis now fifty or sixty years since,</br>(The date of a charming old boy of a Prince)</br>Since the feathered god Mercury happened to lose</br>A thing no less precious than one of his shoes:</br>I say no less precious, because in the mention</br>The artist has made of this very invention,</br>(Old Homer, who furnished the gods with such things)</br>He says, 'twas immortal, of gold, and had wings.</br>The latter indeed are as famous as Love's,</br>And they rivalled in hue even Venus's doves;</br>For at every fresh turn, and least touch into light,</br>Which the clear God of Eloquence took in his flight,</br>They varied their colours in fifty directions,</br>And perfectly dazzled with brilliant reflections.

'I wonder,' said Mercury, — putting his head</br>One rosy-faced morning from Venus's bed,—</br>'I wonder, my dear Cytherea, — don't you?—</br>What can have become of that rogue of a shoe.</br>I've searched every corner to make myself certain,</br>And lifted, I'm sure, ev'ry possible curtain,</br>And how I'm to manage, by Jove, I don't know,</br>For manage I must, and to earth I must go.</br>'Tis now a whole week since I lost it; and here,</br>Like a dove whom your urchin has crippled, my dear,</br>Have I loitered, and fluttered, and looked in those eyes,</br>While Juno keeps venting her crabbed surprise;</br>And Apollo, with all that fine faith in his air,</br>Asks me daily accounts of Rousseau and Voltaire,</br>And Jove (whom it's awkward to risk such a thing with)</br>Has not enough thunder to frighten a king with.</br>So — there then — now don't look so kind, I beseech you,</br>Or else I shall stay a week longer, you witch you—</br>I can't ask the gods; but I'll search once again</br>For this fugitive shoe, and if still it's in vain,</br>I must try to make something a while of sheer leather,</br>And match with a mortal my fair widowed feather.'

So saying, the God put a leg out of bed,</br>And summoned his winged cap on to his head;</br>And the widow in question flew smack round his foot,</br>And up he was getting to end his pursuit,</br>When Venus said softly (so softly, that he</br>Turned about on his elbow) — 'What!  go without me?'

Now the fact was, that Venus, who always would please a</br>Fine wit, had been reading the New Eloisa,</br>And having prodigiously felt and admired it,</br>Couldn't but say so to him who inspired it.</br>Therefore, to take the due steps for expressing</br>Her sense of such very well-worded caressing,</br>She had sent down to earth this same Shoe with an errand</br>To get a new pair at Ashburton for her, and</br>Not think of returning without what it went for,</br>Unless by its master especially sent for.</br>The Shoe made a scrape; and concluding the thing</br>Had been settled 'twixt her and his master, took wing;</br>And never ceased beating through sunshine and rain,</br>Now clasped in a cloud, and now loosened again,</br>Till it came to Ashburton, where something so odd</br>Seemed to strike it, it could not help saying, 'My God!'

I know not precisely how much of this matter</br>Was mentioned, when Mercury sparkled round at her;</br>But Venus proposed, that as one Shoe was fled,</br>Her good easy virtue should help him instead</br>'You know, love,' said she, ''tis as light as a feather;</br>And so I'll be guide, and we'll go down together.'

I leave you to fancy how little he checked her:</br>They chalked out their journey, got up, took their nectar;</br>And then, with his arm round her waist, and his eyes</br>Looking thanks upon hers, came away from the skies.</br>I cannot, I own, say he came much the faster,</br>How earnest soever he looked and embraced her;</br>But never before, though a God of much grace,</br>Had he come with such fine overlooking of face;</br>And as she travelled seldom herself in this style,</br>With a lover beside her, and clasped all the while,</br>'Tis said that the earth was remarkably moved:</br>Even marriers for money imagined they loved:</br>Yes, inanimate things fell exchanging caresses,</br>Till Princes embraced their own legal Princesses:</br>Not one pair of birds or respectable brutes,</br>Nay, not one of gloves, but, they say, followed suits,</br>And the bishops but walked in the steps of their boots.

All felt but one Shoe. — O ye gods from above,</br>Who descended that day with your wit and your love,</br>Assist now my theme, which grows dark at the touch,</br>That I neither may honour nor hate it too much!</br>Yes, all but one Shoe:  not the shoe that was missing,</br>For that one, as much as lay in it, loved kissing;</br>But one which as Venus and Mercury put up</br>Somewhere at Ashburton, nigh tripped her sweet foot up.

The kind Goddess (one of whose charmingest qualities</br>'Tis, at a small thing, to reckon how small it is)</br>Laughed, and said, 'Well, who'd have thought this of you,</br>With that drag in your aspect, my poor little Shoe?</br>Here, come kiss my foot, as a proof we agree:'</br>But the Shoe huffed, — as who should say, 'Don't talk to me'</br>'It wants comprehension,' said Mercury, 'surely,</br>And yet there seems life in it, though it looks poorly.</br>Int'rest, I dare say, will make something of it:</br>My strange little friend, don't you know your own profit?'</br>'Aye, aye, well enough,' said the Shoe in a tone</br>Of uneasy contempt, 'twixt a creak and a groan</br>'I was made for a Squire; and my instinct has told me,</br>That if through the dirt with discretion I hold me</br>My service, some day, will be under an Earl,</br>Which I think's something higher than you and your girl.'

At this, the two Deities set up a shout,</br>Which made all the neighbours leap up and look out:</br>For they thought 'twas the players with music at least,</br>Or that London, or Heaven, was come from the east.</br>But the Shoe, deaf and blind to all beautiful things,</br>Scarce showed more emotion than if 'twere a king's:</br>It did, indeed, slightly perk up its two straps,</br>Like the ears of an ass, when he's sulky, and snaps.

The lovers perceived that it knew not their rank,</br>Or 'twould no more have spurned 'em than kicked at the bank</br>'Twas this that amused 'em. 'But pray, Sir,' said they,</br>'What induced your high Heel-tap to get in our way?'

'Why, I can't bear,' returned this most cross-grained of leathers,</br>'To look at your shoe there, tricked out in such feathers.</br>Why need any shoe be more gifted than I?</br>There was just such another' — (here Venus looked sly,</br>And Hermes guessed all she'd omitted to say)—</br>'Here was just such another came mincing this way,</br>And would fain have come in for some shoes for a Lady;</br>But no, no; I trod on his toes with a 'Hey-day!'</br>On which the fop gave me a cuff with his quill,</br>And whisked away laughing; but I'll pity him still.'

'You had better be quiet,' said Hermes, 'for stuff,</br>Such as yours, can no more wage war with his cuff</br>Than the monster with Perseus, who fell on him, plumed.'</br>'I know,' said the Shoe, as it fretted and fumed.</br>'You do?' said the God; 'then with such an example</br>How monsters should treat the fair sex, would you trample</br>Or offer to do it (for so it now seems)</br>On a foot which surpasses a lover's best dreams?'

'I hate your surpassings, and loves, and all that,'</br>Cried the Shoe, screaming weak like a leather-toed bat;</br>'And since you will have it, I tell you, you fop,</br>That I'd kick the best shoe ever stepped into shop.'

But now the God, angered, shot into that leather</br>A terrible sense of who stood there together,</br>And while it slunk, shaking, half into itself,</br>Denounced it in words, that shall die on no shelf:—

'Vile Soul of a Shoe, — that with decent self-knowledge</br>Had honoured the good man that made thee at college,</br>And walked through the world, if with not many graces,</br>At least in good steps and calm classical places,</br>My very stray slipper that passed thee, and hit,</br>Might have done thee some good, for it brushed thee with wit;</br>But every thing, even Adversity fails,</br>To refine the grain in thee:  the calf-skin prevails.</br>Attend then my curse, while thou shrinkest into thee,</br>And let the ambition thou spoilest, undo thee.

'As soon as I finish my words, thou shalt be,</br>Not a man, for thou canst not, but human to see:</br>Thy appearance at least shall be taken for human,</br>However perplexing to painter or woman.</br>In ev'ry thing else, thou shalt be as thou art,</br>A thing made for dirty ways, hollow at heart.</br>Serve an Earl, as thou say'st; and, in playing the shoe.</br>Let the stories told of thee, malicious or true,</br>Only lead thee hereafter to scandalize too.</br>But let not an Earl stop thy progress; go higher,</br>And at every new step show addition of mire,</br>Like one, who, in climbing a loose-moulded hill,</br>Finds his foot growing heavier and dirtier still,</br>Strain after all those, who ascend to the crown;</br>But all who are falling, assist to kick down:</br>Then getting at top, gape with sycophant joy,</br>And poking about for becoming employ,</br>Make signs thou art ready, with pliable span,</br>To clasp any foot, that would trample on mail.</br>But despair of those nobler ascents, which thou'lt see</br>Stretching far overhead with the Delphian tree,—</br>Holy ground, to climb up to whose least laurelled shelf</br>Thou would'st have to change natures, and put off thyself.</br>Stop, and strain at the base; yet, to ease thy despair,</br>Do thy best to obstruct all the feet that come there,</br>Especially younger ones, winged like mine</br>Till bright, up above thee, they soar and they shine.'</br>Should even the graves, such as lie near the spot,</br>Of critics and note-makers, help thee a jot</br>Be sure to pretend that the heap's of no use</br>And repay those who gave thee a lift with abuse.</br>Dig into their errors, their merits conceal</br>And then shudder to think that the dead can not feel.</br>All things, in short, petty and fit, say and do</br>Becoming a man with the soul of a shoe.</br>Boast thy origin once, because good common-place</br>Has pronounced such behaviour a merit and grace;</br>But after that once, be consistent, and show</br>A great horror of lowness, because it is low:</br>Pick out for thy path, through the region of letters,</br>The very worst tracks that dishonoured thy betters;</br>Like boys, who to get a sensation and splutter,</br>Prefer, to the pavement, a kick through the gutter:</br>Thus, edit no authors but such as unite</br>With their talents a good deal of dirt or of spite;</br>Ben Jonson, because he was beastly and bluff;</br>And Massinger, — mince through his loathsomer stuff</br>And Persius,—"let him be writ down" Imitated</br>And say to poor Juvenal, "Thou art translated."</br>These Latins will help too thy fondest of penchants,</br>And swell thy large hate with the hates of the ancients.</br>But as for such writers as Shakespear and others,—</br>Low fellows, who treated all men as their brothers,</br>Base panders, whose heads ran on love and a wood,</br>Blasphemers, who thought the great Jupiter good,</br>Who had right to be naked, and yet not ashamed,—</br>Be sure to inform us, that they may be damned.</br>I hear some one say, "Murrain take him, the ape!"</br>And so Murrain shall, in a bookseller's shape;</br>An evil-eyed elf, in a down-looking flurry,</br>Who'd fain be a coxcomb, and calls himself Murray.</br>Adorn thou his door, like the sign of the Shoe</br>For court-understrappers to congregate to</br>For Southey to come, in his dearth of invention,</br>And eat his own words for mock-praise and a pension;</br>For Croker to lurk with his spider-like limb in,</br>And stock his lean bag with way-laying the women;</br>And Jove only knows for what creatures beside</br>To shelter their envy and dust-licking pride,</br>And feed on corruption, like bats, who at nights</br>In the dark take their shuffles, which they call their flights.</br>Be these the Court-critics, and vamp a Review;</br>And by a poor figure, and therefore a true,</br>For it suits with thy nature, both shoe-like and slaughterly,</br>Be its hue leathern, and title the Quarterly.</br>Much misconduct it, and see that the others</br>Misdeem, and misconstrue, like miscreant brothers;</br>Misquote, and misplace, and mislead, and misstate,</br>Misapply, misinterpret, misreckon, misdate,</br>Misinform, misconjecture, misargue in short,</br>Miss all that is good, that ye miss not the Court.</br>Count the worth of a mind, not from what it produces,</br>But what it will take to fall in with abuses.</br>Is any one ardent, sincere, independent?</br>What distancing virtue!  Pray try make an end on't.</br>Does any discover what you never could?</br>Pretend it's a trifle no gentleman would.</br>Does a true taste appear for the authors you edit?</br>Take pains, by your scorn, to show you never had it.</br>In short, be the true Representative Tool</br>Of a whole "Court of Coblers" got up into rule.</br>Alas for the country of Harley and Prior!</br>But office shall then be a shop so entire</br>For any dull fellow to keep that can serve,</br>While Britons, turned beggars, are told to go starve,</br>That a whole set of dunces, — yes, Pope, thine own band,</br>Thy Dunciad itself, shall rule over the land!</br>As gutters dive down to re-issue in ditches,</br>Thy divers for pay shall emerge with new riches.</br>Then quality's fools, long be-libelled in vain,</br>In the Stuarts, the Georges, and "Jenkies" shall reign:</br>Then Cymons (not Greek, nor yet mended by Cupid)</br>Shall lord it with faces triumphant as stupid:</br>Happy Page shall be Best, well aware of his fury,</br>Concanen be Croker, and Lintot be Murray:</br>In Southey poor Blackmore, beginning to doat,</br>Shall not only turn a new stave, but his coat:</br>The Wards and the Welsteds shall pamper their spleens,</br>And club in Scotch papers and Scotch Magazines:</br>And finally, thou, my old soul of the tritical,</br>Noting, translating, high slavish, hot critical,</br>Quarterly-scutcheoned, great heir to each dunce,</br>Be Tibbald, Cook, Arnall, and Dennis at once."</br>In one thing alone display nothing in common</br>With dunce any more than with genius, — hate woman.'</br>(Here Venus entreated, and fain would have gone,</br>But the God only clasped her the more, and went on:)</br>'Hate woman, thou block in the path of fair feet;</br>If Fate want a hand to distress them, thing be it;</br>When the Great, and their flourishing vices, are mentioned,</br>Say people "impute" 'em, and show thou art pensioned;</br>But meet with a Prince's old mistress discarded,</br>And then let the world see how vice is rewarded.'

He said.  The poor Shoe, turning restless and wan,</br>Gave a groan, and began struggling up into man.</br>First the straps, falling stiffly, and thrusting the ground,</br>Became arms, by whose help it arose, turning round;</br>Then the toe split in two, and increasing in size,</br>Undertook to support him as legs and as thighs;</br>And lastly from out of the quartering there looked</br>A face at once lachrymose rude, and rebuked.</br>Such a face!  Such a spirit!  For what is a face,</br>But what the soul makes it, for worth or disgrace?
Like a rogue from a regiment be-drummered and fifered,</br>It slunk out of doors, and men called the thing GIFFORD.</br>
